subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Then I would think about splitting the test class in many test classes. Group test cases around a common setup. ... Hold on a second -- what do you want to
messageBody:
On Thursday 26 May 2005 21:47, Cedric Beust wrote:
> Sure, but what if this set up should only be run once for the entire
> class? (which was Allen's original question if I'm not mistaken)

Then I would think about splitting the test class in many test classes.
Group test cases around a common setup.

> For example, imagine that the class to test does some verification on
> an XML file. In this case, the one-time set up should simply parse the
> XML file, create the DOM tree and then use the class to perform various
> verifications on this tree. And of course, we don't want to re-parse
> it every time.

Hold on a second -- what do you want to test, an XML /file/ or the
representation in memory? If you test the transformation from file to
objects in memory, you probably want to parse again in each test with
slightly different XML input.

If you don't want to test the XML to object mapping, then why bother with
XML at all in the test? Just create a bunch of objects to play with and
skip the XML part.

> I can come up with a lot of examples where such a fine grained (or
> coarse grained, in this case) setUp/tearDown life cycle is necessary
> without the tests being dependent on each other.

Please give an example where it does affect your test results if the setup
code runs for each test and where you still claim that the tests are
independent.

Cheers,

Robert
